abstract.p: Registered nurses at Nyack Hospital overwhelmingly reject proposed new contract and vow to continue their four-month-old strike against hospital (M)

block.p: The registered nurses at Nyack Hospital overwhelmingly rejected a proposed new contract and vowed tonight to continue their four-month-old strike against the hospital, in Rockland County.

The contract, which would have given the nurses a 10 percent raise over five years and a say in establishing nurse-patient ratios but which called for a giveback of five sick days, was defeated by a ratio of more than 2 to 1.
The registered nurses at Nyack Hospital overwhelmingly rejected a proposed new contract and vowed tonight to continue their four-month-old strike against the hospital, in Rockland County.

The contract, which would have given the nurses a 10 percent raise over five years and a say in establishing nurse-patient ratios but which called for a giveback of five sick days, was defeated by a ratio of more than 2 to 1.

''It was the sick days and the low salary,'' said Mark Genovese, spokesman for the New York State Association of Nurses, which represents 33,000 nurses statewide. ''The hospital needs to present a more competitive package if they want to keep from losing staff.''
Hospital officials said they would immediately move forward in the process of replacing the striking nurses, by running a national recruitment and advertising campaign.

''It's puzzling to us,'' said Nancy Kriz, a spokeswoman for Nyack Hospital. ''We really did our best to reach an agreement. We bargained in good faith and I believe the union bargained in good faith, too.
''The union said they would recommend it to their membership, but the membership obviously voted it down.''
The nurses have been on strike since Dec. 21, when contract talks broke down.

Each day of the strike nurses picketed in front of the red-brick hospital, drawing honks of support from passing drivers, while inside the 375-bed hospital, care was provided by temporary nurses hired through an agency in Colorado.
The voting, at the Best Western Motel in Nyack, ended at 9 o'clock tonight.
Under the existing contract, which expired in December 1997, nurses started at an annual salary of $42,500 and reached a top salary of $61,400 after 18 years.

Before negotiations broke down in December, the hospital proposed a merit pay scale that would have given all the nurses a raise of 10 percent over five years, and some nurses as much as 22 percent over five years.

The nurses balked at the notion of merit pay, with union leaders saying that a good nurse who is a strong patient advocate but an annoyance to the hospital administration would get lower evaluation ratings and smaller raises.
Under the rejected contract proposal, the merit pay option would have been replaced by a bonus system.
Nurses who got good evaluations and met certain criteria could have received annual bonuses of up to 1.5 percent of their salary under the proposal.

One of the biggest points of contention during the strike has been whether to add a clause to the contract specifying a nurse-to-patient ratio for the various hospital wards. The proposed contract called for a team made up equally of management and nurses to establish nurse-to-patient ratios based on the severity of the illnesses of the patients.

This is the third time in seven years that the nurses have been on strike at Nyack Hospital. In 1993, they went on strike for six and a half hours when contract negotiations took longer than expected. In 1995, a 26-day strike, called because the hospital wanted to eliminate all 12-hour shifts, ended in a compromise.
